text:
What's really different
about the case method
is that it's a conversation.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Unlike with articles or
books, where we're basically

pontificating and hoping
that other people are

buying what we say and
understanding what we say,

when we're teaching
in case, we actually

hear people grappling
in real time

with the particulars
of the case,

but then also applying it
to their own situation.

For me, the biggest
difference pedagogically

teaching with case studies is
it shifts the roles from teacher

has the answers to
students discover them.

I think because of the dynamic
nature of the discussions

that we have in
class, the case method
is so helpful for testing ideas.
It's a very iterative process.

And I think the work becomes
better because students are not

only receiving that
information, but sharing

their insights based on their
practices, their experiences,
their knowledge.

Learning is about
knowing, doing, and being.

And the beauty of the
case method for me

is that it enables me to do all
three things in the classroom
with my students.

And so a session
is never the same.

It may be the same case, but
new questions are raised.

And this is what makes it a
truly wonderful tool for us

as instructors and, I
think, for the students.

By allowing the students
to see themselves

in the eyes and the experiences
of a case protagonist,

we can bring to life
various different aspects
of organizational behavior.

You can actually see how
that theory plays out

in the experiences
of that individual

and allow students to
step into their shoes

and say, if I were
this particular person,
how might I handle it.

And in many ways,
the case study method

enables us to really deliver
on our promise of marrying
research and practice.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
